vulnerability_findings.name: inefficient-state-variable-increment
vulnerability_findings.message: <x> += <y> costs more gas than <x> = <x> + <y> for state variables.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require (balances[msg.sender]>=_amount && _amount>0 && balances[_to]+_amount>balances[_to], "Insufficient amount or allowance error");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(_from != address(0), "Sender cannot be zero address");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(_to != address(0), "Recipient cannot be zero address");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require (balances[_from]>=_amount && allowed[_from][msg.sender]>=_amount && _amount>0 && balances[_to]+_amount>balances[_to], "Insufficient amount or allowance error");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(account != address(0), "BEP20: mint to the zero address");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(account != address(0), "BEP20: burn from the zero address");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(accountBalance >= amount, "BEP20: burn amount exceeds balance");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(addressToBeChanged != address(0) && addressToSend != address(0), "Change addresses cannot be zero");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(to != address(0), "No mint to zero address");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require (balances[msg.sender]>=_amount && _amount>0 && balances[_to]+_amount>balances[_to], "Insufficient amount or allowance error");
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require (balances[_from]>=_amount && allowed[_from][msg.sender]>=_amount && _amount>0 && balances[_to]+_amount>balances[_to], "Insufficient amount or allowance error");
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(addressToBeChanged != address(0) && addressToSend != address(0), "Change addresses cannot be zero");
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require (balances[msg.sender]>=_amount && _amount>0 && balances[_to]+_amount>balances[_to], "Insufficient amount or allowance error");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require (balances[_from]>=_amount && allowed[_from][msg.sender]>=_amount && _amount>0 && balances[_to]+_amount>balances[_to], "Insufficient amount or allowance error");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(account != address(0), "BEP20: burn from the zero address");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(accountBalance >= amount, "BEP20: burn amount exceeds balance");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.
